author: pipermerriam
content: I'm a VERY STRONG üëé on any code merklization approaches that are tied to EVM semantics.  The bytecode should be opaque bytes.  Otherwise we bind the EVM semantics to the merklization scheme and end up with some really costly interdependencies somewhere down the line....

author: sky.cactus
content: As an engineer who has, on occasion, found themselves having to read bytecode or decompiled bytecode, I would appreciate higher level structures in the bytecode itself.  Reading CLR and Java bytecode, for example, is *way* easier than reading x86 bytecode.  This isn't a strong argument to add these features to the EVM, but it does make me appreciate the value a bit and why static analyzers would prefer it.

author: .vbuterin
content: My general philosophy here is that I would like ethereum state (including accounts, code chunks and storage) to operate on an abstraction layer above a single key/value tree. Because this minimizes client code complexity, and makes it easier to upgrade the tree structure (eg. to STARK witnesses once we need post-quantum) in the future

author: sky.cactus
content: So basically Ethereum state storage systems should not ever need to know anything about *what* it is storing?

author: .vbuterin
content: right, exactly

author: gcolvin
content: The Solidity team has generally not sent a representative to ACD calls.  I don't know why not.  But therefore they never participated in the final consensus to include it.  I agree this is unfortunate.  If they oppose it now the appropriate course of action is to place an item on the Agenda for the ACD call and send a representative.

author: .vbuterin
content: The other way to describe this is that the ethereum state should be able to be stored in arbitrary generic state storage layers, which could also be used without modification for other blockchains (incl rollups) if people want. And key/value store is the most general-purpose standard that you can get.

author: tkstanczak
content: Imagine that you are one of the technical committee of a car producing company and you are about to approve a change to the design of the engines. You go to your expert engine mechanics and all of them say: well, you can do that if you want but we will not use it. It is ready to be introduced, was already approved by other people so it is easy to simply approve it too. Then you keep going around the factory asking who needs it and nobody needs it. You let them read the spec and they say - ' well it is not that good, really, but you can do that, we simply not going to use it'. ...also you are being told that it is an obvious improvement because this is what has been introduced in airplane engines in 70s.
